Journal.Title: Journal of the Air & Waste Management Association (1995)

Article.ArticleTitle: Ozone sensitivity to high energy demand day electricity and onroad emissions during LISTOS.

AbstractText: High-resolution coupled meteorology-chemistry modeling in the New York City and surrounding areas is used to model changes in ozone air quality resulting from region-wide onroad transportation emission reductions and NO<sub>X</sub> reductions from high energy demand day (HEDD) electricity generating units (EGUs). Although reducing onroad emissions by 90% produces the largest change in ozone concentrations, the results also suggest that the ozone photochemical regime becomes more NOx-sensitive as emissions from major regional sectors like onroad transportation continue to decline. Despite being highly localized and variable, emissions from HEDD EGUs can have an added impact on reducing ambient ozone concentrations. As the ozone production regime in the region shifts from VOC-sensitive to NOx-sensitive, the impacts of NOx-titration in the urban core weaken and ozone is more likely to decline with a decrease in NOx emissions such as from HEDD units.
